result.heading: ROLL CREDITS AND THEME MUSIC DISSOLVE TO

direction.raw_text: The crust of an old snowfall still covers the frozen ground, and the bare, icy branches of the trees glisten dully in the early morning light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is standing in front of a blank green wall gesticulating animatedly at some invisible images on the wall, talking a mile a minute (MOS) . He looks completely crazy as he points at nothing and winks to an unseen audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as we streak across the winter landscape, flying over fields and farms, small towns and hamlets, railroad lines and interstates, coalyards and factories, until we cross the Allegheny River and follow it to the southwest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil continues pointing out features on the blank wall , but from a new angle we can see that he ' s looking at a monitor out of the corner of his eye which shows the chromakey insert he's pointing to -- a national weather map.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The country towns turn to suburbs, traffic on the roads gets heavier and finally we see the skyline of Pittsburgh and the confluence of the Allegheny with the Monongahela and the Ohio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We zoom into a tall building in the downtown area and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't see anyone at first but the office itself speaks volumes about it's inhabitant-- team pictures of the Steelers from the Franco Harris-Terry Bradshaw glory years, a framed memorial portrait of Roberto Clemente, a local Emmy award statue, an erasable weather map and mountains of personal junk on the desk, ^windowsill, and every other available surface. As the CREDITS END, we notice a sleeping figure on the small sofa, buried deep under a pile of coats and a stolen airline blanket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Executive Producer of the Action News, sticks his head in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ, what a pit. Phil" The sleeping figure rouses himself and looks out at Hawley. It's Phil, the .Channel 9 Action News weatherman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's February first, Phil. You know what tomorrow is? Phil sits up and.thinks hard. He's in his mid-thirties, smart, rugged-looking, perhaps a little too full of himself, but clearly a guy with a lot of personality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (catching on) Oh, no! Not again. He jumps up and exits the office with Hawley right behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it! I'm not going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hawley pursues Phil through the office suite of the Channel 9 Action News, from the look of it a typical, big city, local news operation. A logo on the wall identifies the station as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Pittsburgh. Phil ducks into the studio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STUDIO - CONTINUOUS Hawley follows him in and catches up with him at the weather corner of the Action News set. Phil starts putting weather stats up on a chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get away from me. I'm working.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's the outlook? We gonna get that blizzard? Phil shakes his head and points to the chart which is headed "Phil's Phorecast" with a cute caricature of himself drawn next to the title.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No way. All that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us completely and take a dump on Harrisburg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with authority) Good, 'cause you're going up to Punxsutawney to cover the groundhog story tomorrow morning and I want you back here in time to do the five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, Gil, give me a break, will you! I covered the goddamn groundhog last year and the year before that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you'll do it :next year and the year after, too. When I worked in San Diego, I covered the swallows coming back to Capistrano for ten years in a row.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should've killed the guy who made you do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you should've killed yourself. I don't want to get stuck with the groundhog for the rest of my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a cute story. He comes out, he looks around, he wrinkles up his little nose, he sniffs around a little, he sees his shadow, he d oesn't see his shadow-- it's nice. People like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Many people are morons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'11 you give me? Hawley looks across the studio and sees RITA HANSON enter, a very attractive segment producer in her late twenties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Phil) I'll give you Rita. (calls her over) Rita, could you come here for a second? I got a little job for you. Rita is relatively new to the station, but very competent, personable, humorous, self-assured and very pretty-- in short, a genuine princess, though Phil is too self-absorbed at this point to realize it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't send Rita out on a story like this. She's just a cub, a pup, still wet behind the ears. Look at her. Her ears are sopping wet. This needs a Woodward or a Bernstein. It's a big story. People need to know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the story?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Punxsutawney Groundhog Festival.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gil, if it's all right with you I ' d rather follow-up on the nurses' strike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can do the nurses when you get back. Just take the squeaky wheel here up to Punxsutawney and get him back in one piece. Okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, okay. Hawley exits leaving Phil and Rita alone in the studio. She knows Phil mainly by his reputation and it isn't good. Still, she finds him appealing in an odd way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, this could be extremely interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never done a weather story before. What's Punxsutawney like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's an enchanted place. A magical world. It's the Constantinople of the whole Western Appalachian-Susquehanna Drainage system.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you always joke?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About 70 to 80% of the time. Inside I'm actually a very shy and sensitive person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A lot of people around here think you're not very sincere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me the names of these people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll line up a crew and transportation. If you don't feel like driving, we can all go up in the van together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'll take my own car. I ' m not that fond of my fellow man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice attitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice face. (calls after her) Why don't you ride up with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , an attractive, dark-eyed, dark-haired correspondent, glares at Phil from across the studio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil is in his cluttered cubicle talking on a headset phone while he reviews cassettes of his groundhog spots from the past two years on a small monitor. As he talks, he stuffs a number of personal items in an overnight bag, all the time watching himself on the TV monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on the phone) They don't really think of me as a weatherman around here. More of a "personality," but with the credibility of a first-class broadcast journalist. Once you look at my tape I think you'll see what they mean. Stephanie enters and stands in the doorway looking at Phil for a long moment. There is something vaguely off-center about this woman, not quite FATAL ATTRACTION but still a little scary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just want to know one thing: did I do something wrong or are you just tired of me or what? I have to know. Phil sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on the phone) Dan, can I call you back? I've just been handed something and I better get on it... (he picks up some papers and rustles them for effect) ...Okay, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes off the headset, gets up and closes the door for privacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't do anything wrong, Stephanie, and I ' m not tired of you. It's just that I don't have time for a real relationship right now. I told you that the first time we went out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (getting close) Everybody says that at the beginning of a relationship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gently pushing her
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ) I'm different. I really meant it! Things are really starting to move for me now. I ' m not going to be doing the weather for the rest of my life. I was just talking to the CBS guy about a network job. I want that. This is just the beginning for me. I can't waste any more time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you saying our relationship was a waste of time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our relationship? We went out a total of four times! And only twice did anything happen. It was fun but I don't see that as a big commitment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (closing in again) I had our charts done. My astrologer says we're extremely compatible. There may even be some past lives involvement here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See? So we've already done this. Let's move on. Next case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what's wrong with you, Phil? You're selfish. You don't have time for anyone but yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what I ' m trying to tell you. You don't want to be with me. You can do better. Look, Stephanie, if I ever said or did anything to mislead you I'm sorry for that, but right now I have to do this groundhog thing and I don't have a handle on it yet. He throws some papers and his datebook into a briefcase and puts on his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONT.) I'll tell you what. I ' m going to do some serious thinking while I ' m in Punxsutawney, okay? He pats her on the shoulder and brushes past her, leaving her standing there with a malevolent look on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: marked ".Channel 9 Action News" speeds along a two-lane highway through the winter landscape of West Central Pennsylvania. Mounted atop the van is a microwave transmitter. Rita is riding up front with LARRY, the union cameraman and techie. Phil is following close behind the van in a new Lexus coupe. His car has a bumper-sticker that reads "Weathermen Like it Wet."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (on his earphone) I'm on my way to Punxsutawney... (forced to repeat it, a little embarrassed) Punx^su-taw-ney....Work or fun? I think that all depends on you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil is talking to one of his girlfriends, sorting through a stack of CD's, as usual, grabbing at the good life with both hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . . . . I thought maybe you could meet me up there tonight and let me vulgarize you for about seven hours....So I ' m supposed to spend the night in Punxsutawney all alo ne? Thanks. Phil loads a CD and a great, driving song kicks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Welcome to Punxsutawney - The Original Weather Capitol of the World Since 1887." Depicted on the sign is a large cartoon
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wearing a top hat and clutching an umbrella under his arm. The mini-convoy passes some fast food places on the outskirts of town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The van drives along , the small-town main drag. There are cartoon groundhogs everywhere you look and the whole town has been gaily festooned with banners and bunting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOTEL - LATER The van pulls into the parking lot at a Quality Inn. The announcement billboard in ;front of the motel reads: "Groundhog Day Breakfast Special - Feb.2 - All You Can Eat - $5.99." The parking area is already crowded with cars including a number of other news vans. The Lexus pulls in behind the van and everybody gets out. Phil takes one look at the motel and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calls out) Rita! I can't stay here. Rita is already helping Larry unload equipment from the van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prima donnas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay. I'll handle it. She crosses to the Lexus where Phil is trying to make another call on his earphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the problem, Phil?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate this place. I stayed here two years ago and I was miserable. It's like a minimum security prison. I'm not staying here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not staying here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ' m not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Larry and I don't care but I thought you might, so I booked you at a very nice bed and breakfast on Cherry Street. Here's the address. She hands him a card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great. That's great. That's the mark of a really good producer. Making the talent happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever I can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Will you be my love slave?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever I can do within reason. Would you like to have dinner with Larry and me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thanks, I've seen Larry eat. Why don't you ditch Larry and let me take you someplace nice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean like a date?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. I get it. You're a little intimidated by me, you're all excited about the shoot tomorrow, you want everything to go just perfect. I understand. You just get some sleep. Tomorrow will be great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's something to look forward to. I'll see you in the morning. He drives off, leaving her standing there shaking her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he actually call himself "the talent?" Larry snorts and continues unloading their gear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first light of morning colors the sky behind the Cherry Street Inn, a rambling, white Victorian bed and breakfast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP - CLOCK A digital clock-radio changes from 5:59 to 6:00 AM. The radio comes on, playing the end of the Sonny and Cher hit, "I Got You, Babe."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FEBRUARY 2 INT. PHIL'S ROOM - DAWN Phil sits up in bed and looks around the room. The decor is typical bed and breakfast, flocked wallpaper, framed prints, and an odd assortment of mismatched furniture. His suit is hanging neatly on the back of the closet door and his suitcase is open on a stand at the foot of the bed, still neatly packed. A iradio, DEEJAY and his SIDEKICK come on with hyped-up, drivetime Chappy talk." Phil stares at the radio and listens to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil grimaces and swings out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's cold out there everyday. W hat is this-- Miami Beach? The deejay laughs. Phil shakes his head at the cheesy repartee as he crosses to the sink and starts brushing his teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not hardly. And you can expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That "blizzard thing?" Phil splashes some water on his face and prepares to shave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONT.) Oh, here's the report: the National Weather Service is calling for a big blizzard thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes they are, but there's another reason today is very special--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Es pec ia lly cold--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially cold, okay, but the big question on everybody's lips--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ch ap pe d lips--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :--on their chapped lips, right-- Do you think Phil's going to come out and see his shadow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Punxsutawney Phil. Phil looks up at himself in the mirror, admiring his own face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, rodent lovers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Groundhog Day1
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of GRUNTING GROUNDHOGS. Phil grunts at his reflection in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) Never again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR - DAWN Phil heads for the breakfast room of the inn, now well-dressed in a suit and tie, a nice overcoat slung over his arm. A CHUBBY MAN passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think it'll be an early Spring?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ' m predicting March 21st.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil enters the old library of the house now set up with a breakfast buffet. An old spinet piano stands in the corner. One wall is lined with .bookcases filled with books. A handful of guests are seated around the room, eating. The matron of the house, MRS. LANCASTER, spots Phil as she comes out of the kitchen with a fresh pot of coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCASTER Did you sleep well, Mr. Connors?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with mock civility) Like a Roumanian orphan, Mrs. Lancaster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCASTER Would you like some coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't suppose it1 d be possible to get an espresso or a capuccino around here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCASTER (BLANKLY) I don't really know -- PHIL Forget it. This '11 be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCASTER ( as she pours) I wonder what the weather's going to be like for all the festivities.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My guess is it'11 be cold and overcast, high today in the low
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: s, dropping to the low 20's tonight, but I'm predicting that all that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us and dump some locally heavy snow, possibly blizzard conditions with travel advisories in the Harrisburg area and maybe as far east as .Philadelphia. (off her surprised
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ) You want to talk weather, you asked the right guy. He heads for the door. ;MRS. LANCASTER : Oh, will you be checking out today, Mr. Connors?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unfortunately yes. Phil exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sipping at the steaming coffee, Phil manages to put on his coat and gloves as he descends the front steps of the house and joins the flow of pedestrian traffic on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are a lot of people on the street for this hour. Traffic is so heavy in fact, the pedestrians are moving faster than the cars. Everyone seems to be going in the same direction, making the annual trek to see the groundhog. An OLD BUM is sitting on the sidewalk leaning against a storefront. Someone throws him a coin. Phil walks by without taking any notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.C.) Hey, Phil!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big pie-faced man, NED RYERSON, comes huffing and puffing right up to him. There is something about this guy that makes us dislike him on sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you! Phil looks at him vaguely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (at a loss) I 'm sorry. Have we-- uh--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My oh my! Phil Connors. Don't say you don't remember me, 'cause I sure as heckrfire remember you. Well? Phil stares, trying to remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned Ryerson? Needlenose Ned? Ned the Head. Come on, buddy. Case Western High?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you clicking through that brain of yours. Click-click, c li ck- cli ck, click-click--Bing! Ned Ryerson, did the whistling trick with my belly button in the talent show. Bing! Ned Ryerson, got the shingles real bad senior ^year^ almost didn't graduate. Bing again! Ned Ryerson, went out with your sister Mary Pat a couple of times-- 'til you told me not to anymore. Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned Ryerson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what're you doing with yourself, Ned?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil, I sell insurance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sorry he asked) No kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have life insurance, Phil? 'Cause if you do, I bet you could u s e more-- who couldn't?--but I got a feeling you don't have any. Am I right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Ned, I ' d love to talk to you but I really have to-- Phil starts to walk away,,but Ned won't take the hint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay. I'll walk with you. When I see an opportunity, I charge it, like a bull. Ned the Bull, that's me now. Some of my friends live and die by actuarial tables, but I think it's all just a crap shoot anyhoo. Ever heard of single .premium life? That could be the ticket for you, buddy. God, it's good to see you! Hey, what're you doing for dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dinner? Umm, I don't think that's going to work for me. As they continue walking, Phil steps into what looks like a shallow puddle and ends up ankle deep in wet slush. Ned laughs like a donkey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, look out for that first step! It's a doozy! Phil looks at him with murderous contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big crowd is standing in a park-like clearing off a residential street. They are gathered around a large mound of dirt enclosed by a rail fence, waiting for the big moment. For a cold gray dawn, there is the atmosphere of a festival here. An area close to the mound is roped off for news reporters and cameras. Rita stands there, a pocket of genuine beauty in this sea of potbellied old union guys and blow-dried reporters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stomping her feet against the cold, Rita looks at her watch and glances around. Larry, the cameraman, just looks bored.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could he be late?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prima donnas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just so-- inconsiderate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happens to some people? They're born nice. They grow up nice. You put 'em on TV and - bam! Prima donnas. Rita spots Phil heading into the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here he comes. Phil! Hey, Phil. Over here! Phil joins them in the press area. Rita pulls him to his mark near the rail fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where've you been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got hung up with some jerk I went to high school with. So, did you sleep okay without me? You tossed and turned, didn't you? Rita holds up a slate for Larry to ID the tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're incredible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who told you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready when you are. Phil takes the microphone from Rita and positions himself against the fence. The Groundhog Club Officials in top hats, striped trousers and cutaway coats parade out to the burrow that houses Punxsutawney Phil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like they're starting. Roll tape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rolling. Rita silently counts down from five and cues Phil who instantly snaps into announce mode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to camera) Once a year, the eyes of the nation turn here, to this tiny hamlet in Pennsylvania, to watch a master at work. The master? Punxsutawney Phil, the world's most famous weatherman, the groundhog, who, as legend has it, can predict the coming of an early spring. Rita turns to Larry. This is impressive-- so far, so good. A Groundhog Club Official kneels at the burrow and ceremoniously knocks on the small wooden door, then opens it and retreats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And here's the big moment we've all been waiting for. Let's just see what Mr. Groundhog has to say. The groundhog sticks his head out, looks around, steps out of the hole, and runs over to the other side of the mound, about as far away from the cameras as he can get.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! Over here, you little weasel! Larry zooms in as far as he can but the best he can manage is a close-up of the groundhog's back. The groundhog stands there a moment, his body casting a long shadow, then he lets out a squeak and runs back into the hole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great shot, huh, folks? Well, that was certainly worth the trip. Now we'll be hearing from Mr. Buster Greene, President of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club, the so-called Seer of Seers who will interpret for us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dressed up in his top hat and cutaway coat, walks onto the mound and hushes the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He came out, and he saw his shadow. Sorry, ladies and gentlemen, but it looks like it's going to be a long winter. The crowd lets out a good-natured "Awwwwww" in disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sarcastic, to camera) Well, that's it. Sorry you couldn't be here in person to share the electric moment. This is one event where televison really fails to capture the excitement of thousands of people gathered to watch a large squirrel predict the weather, and I for one am deeply grateful to have been a part of it. Reporting for Channel 9, this is Phil Connors. Larry cuts the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Phil) You want to try one that's a little sweeter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Rita) That's as sweet as I get. I'm outa here. As he exits, Phil tosses the mike to Larry, who isn't expecting the throw and bobbles it, dropping the mike on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prima donnas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINER - LATER Phil is sitting alone having a cup of coffee in a busy, loud and lively cafe. Rita enters, sees him sitting there, crosses to his table and sits down across from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was really lousy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it my fault the little rat went south on us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A real professional would have handled it. You acted like it was a personal insult. Who do you think you are -- Wolf Blitzer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, you really take this stuff seriously, don't you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I do. As far as I ' m concerned there are no little stories, Phil. Only little reporters with big egos who think they're too good for the job they have to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to look hurt) You really don't know me very well, do you. 'Cause if you did you could never say something like that about me. I care! Call me a cockeyed optimist but I happen to think there's more to this job than just getting my ugly mug on the boob tube every night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that is so. Rita is so irritated by him she can't even respond. Phil looks at her evenly for a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So as far as us getting together, would you say the glass is half empty or half full? Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around, spots Rita and makes his way over to their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to camera) We ll, it's Groundhog Day-- again-- and you know what that means. Everybody's here on Gobbler's Knob waiting in the cold for the appearance of the most famous groundhog in the world, Punxsutawney Phil, who's going to tell us just how much more of this we can expect. The Groundhog Club Official knocks on the groundhog's door, then opens it and retreats. Phil takes a deep breath and makes his first experimental prediction, recalling the previous day.

direction.raw_text: My forecast is we're going to see the groundhog peek its head out of its hole, look around a little bit, then he's going to come out, scamper over to this general area, look at the crowd for a second, make a little burping noise and run back into the ground.

direction.raw_text: (whispers to Larry) That's it. I'm going to kill him. Phil looks at his watch.

direction.raw_text: O k ay ? And here we go-- Phil points to the hole and Larry zooms in. The groundhog sticks his head out, looks left, looks right, steps out of the hole, and runs away from the press pool, directly over to Larry's camera. As he stands there, his body casts a long shadow. The groundhog looks right into the camera, lets out a squeak, and runs back into the hole. Rita and Larry are completely amazed as the crowd cheers the brief appearance of the groundhog. Larry pans back to Phil. Phil just stands there speechless, staring at the groundhog burrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil! Buster Greene, the Groundhog club official, walks onto the mound and hushes the crowd, exactly as before.

Again the crowd lets out a good-natured "Awwwwww" in disappointment. Larry pans back to Phil just in time to see him walking away in a fog, without signing off. Then he pans back to Rita.

direction.raw_text: (at a loss) For Channel 9 News, this is Rita Hanson in Punxsutawney. She holds for a moment then makes the cut sign, drawing her finger across her throat.

direction.raw_text: : - LATER INT; PHIL'S ROOM Phil is on the phone desperately trying to make a call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on the phone) I know there's a blizzard, but I have to get a call through to my doctor in Pittsburgh. It's a medical emergency. . . .No, don't give me the Punxsutawney Fire Department. When do you think the long distance lines will be working again?. . . But what if we don't have a tomorrow? We didn't have one today, my friend... Hello...Hello? He hangs up and shakes his head which is now really starting to ache, then he pops a handful of Tylenol, lies down and pulls the covers up over his head. A moment later, he sits up, takes a pencil from the nightstand, breaks it in half and puts the pieces back on the nightstand. Then he lies back down and retreats back under the covers.

direction.raw_text: . BED AND BREAKFAST - CONTINUOUS Phil enters and passes Mrs. Lancaster in the breakfast room.

direction.raw_text: Phil enters and dumps the bags on the bed. Out fall a couple of big paintbrushes, a small sledgehammer, a handsaw, a crowbar, plastic goggles and assorted other tools. He puts on the goggles, grabs a hammer and some nails and starts nailing the door shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR - LATER Mrs. Lancaster and several other guests are gathered in the hall outside Phil's room, listening at the door and looking very worried. Loud music is playing inside the room. From inside the room, they hear the sound of loud hammering, wood splintering and glass breaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil, has demolished just about all the furniture and woodwork in the room. He rips off the last of the wooden moldings with the crowbar, then crosses to the mirror over the demolished sink. Phil stands there, staring at his image in the mirror, trying to figure out what's happening to him. He starts breathing heavier, as if gathering courage, then, just when we think he's going to cut off his ear or something, he raises an electric barber clipper and shaves a bald stripe up the middle of his head. He studies his new look for a moment then smashes the mirror with his sledgehammer. Then he opens the cans of paint, dips the two big brushes into the cans and starts slapping bright red paint onto the walls, madly, feverishly, splashing himself and everything else in the room with it. As a final touch he grabs the bed pillows and rips them open, then shakes them all around the room creating a storm of feathers. Finally, Phil falls exhausted on the bed. From outside we can hear outraged hotel employees pounding on the door. We pan over to the clock radio, the only undamaged object in the room. Feathers drift down past the face of the clock which reads 5:59 AM. The time changes to 6:00, the radio clicks on and "I Got You, Babe" starts playing as we pan back to Phil sleeping on the bed. He opens his eyes, jumps out of bed and looks around. No paint, no feathers, no damage. Everything is as clean and tidy as the day he checked in. He races over to the unbroken mirror and looks at himself. His hair is completely restored, as if it had never been shaved. The song ends and the deejays come on. Phil says every word right along with them, shocked into a state of complete wonderment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there today.

direction.raw_text: In fact, the groundhog's legendary ability to predict the weather may be more than just the German folklore of the region. Higher temperatures trigger hormonal changes in the testosterone levels of male groundhogs, which may in fact wake them from hibernation and send them out to battle with other males ;for mating rights. So, the truth is they're not looking for their shadows, they're looking for groundhog chicks. Rita looks on, clearly delighted with the report.

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And so began my final lifetime, and ended the longest winter on record. I would find myself no longer able to affect the chain of events in this town, but I did learn something about time. You can waste time, you can kill time, you can do time, but if you use it wisely, there's never enough of it. So you'd better make the most of the time you've got. A car skids on the ice and smashes into a tree. Phil and Rita rush over to help, but the driver waves that he's okay. Rita and Phil continue their walk.
